newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Minproc says half yr loss A$24.4 mln.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Minproc says half yr loss A$24.4 mln.

text.p: Minproc Engineers Ltd said on Wednesday that it would undertake a fully underwritten rights issue to all shareholders due to a capital deficiency arising from provisions made in the first six months of 1996/97.

The mining engineer said in a statement that it made a net loss of A$24.43 million in the latest half year compared with a A$17.39 million loss a year ago. It said its shares had been suspended at the request of directors.
The latest loss included an abnormal loss of A$27.8 million, which included a provision of A$19.1 million to account for problems with the Yolanda Nitrates project in Chile.
Minproc said the remainder of the abnormal loss consisted of A$4.7 million for other contractural provisions and A$4.0 million for intangibles.
It said the share suspension had been sought due to the latest loss and the recapitalisation proposal which should be agreed over the next two to four weeks.

An agreement had been reached with other parties in the Yolanda dispute which included a payment by Minproc of US$7.5 million to creditors of Minproc Overseas Projects Pty Ltd which is operating under voluntary administration. There are 78 creditors, Minproc said.

The Yolanda deal would consist of paying a total of US$800,000 to 78 creditors in full who are owed amounts of less than US$100,000. A further US$6.7 million of new shares in Minproc would be issued to 10 Chilean-based creditors whose claims exceed US$100,000 at an issue price of A$0.45 per share.
These shares would not be listed or have any voting rights for two years.

It said Minproc's largest shareholder, Union Gold Mining Co NL, had indicated it supported the recapitalisation of Minproc by way of a rights issue. Details of the issue were not given but would be released soon, Minproc said.
Minproc chairman Brettney Fogarty said the payment to Yolanda creditors was designed to end grave uncertainties flowing from certain guarantees agreed to by the previous board of Minproc.
"We have, in effect, inherited a disaster and been forced to do the cleaning up," he said.
Minproc announced a rise in 1996/97 first half sales to A$93.57 million from A$68.44 million a year ago.
Operating profit was A$3.36 million compared with a A$5.39 million loss previously.
